awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Microwave ablation system for creating precision directed ablation zones
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this SBIR Phase II project proposes continued development of a directional microwave ablation (MWA) system. During MWA, doctors use image guidance to insert a thin needle-like applicator into a target tumor and then energize the microwave antenna embedded in the applicator’s tip to heat and kill the tumor. MWA is especially important to the large population of cancer patients who are poor candidates for surgery or other physically demanding therapies, such as chemotherapy or radiation therapy, due to tumor location or poor health. All currently available MWA systems are only capable of producing a roughly spherical or teardrop-shaped treatment zone centered on the axis of the applicator, which is not suitable for treating tumors located near critical anatomy or irregularly shaped targets. This limitation often leaves doctors with a difficult choice of risking undertreatment and disease recurrence or risking overtreatment and damage to critical healthy anatomy that may cause pain or life-threatening complications. Directional MWA would allow the physician to instead place the applicator alongside the tumor and direct heat toward the target and away from nearby sensitive tissues. New clinical techniques enabled by directional MWA could facilitate faster, safer, more effective, and lower cost treatment of localized tumors, and potentially broaden the range of diseases that could be treated in a minimally invasive manner.

As microwave antennas typically require physically large structures to achieve a high degree of directivity, developing a small diameter (<2.0 mm) applicator suitable for minimally invasive treatments is technically challenging and requires the use of novel design methods, fabrication processes, and materials. Technical work in this Phase II projects includes: 1) Industrialized design of the prototype ablation applicator and transmission cable hub, and associated fabrication and assembly process development to improve quality and clinical usability;  2) Testing and characterization of clinical delivery parameters, and developing an algorithm that informs treatment planning for the creation of customizable treatment zones;  3) Development of a programmable multi-channel MW generator platform, affording customizable control of energy delivery parameters, and 4) Detailed system integration and in vivo system performance assessment and characterization to develop treatment planning and dosing guidelines. We will employ an approach integrating multiphysics computational models, benchtop experimentation in ex vivo tissue, and in vivo experiments in porcine liver and kidney to design, optimize, and validate our applicators and integrated microwave ablation system. The goal of this R&D effort is to complete the technical design of a clinically viable directional microwave ablation system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Through our National Science Foundation Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II grant, Precision Microwave was successfully able to industrialize the design of our novel directional microwave ablation applicator and develop the remaining components to form a fully functional system. We successfully validated the performance of our directional microwave ablation system through extensive benchtop testing, use by veterinarians in pre-clinical in vivo large animal studies, and demonstrations for clinical users and industry professionals. With the completion of our Phase II research and development work, Precision Microwave is well positioned to seek investments/partnerships to support the remaining regulatory and safety testing leading to our FDA 510(k) submission and first-in-human clinical trials.

Microwave ablation treatments are especially important to the large number of cancer patients who are poor candidates for surgery or other physically demanding therapies like chemotherapy or radiation therapy. During microwave ablation, needle-like applicators embedded with microwave antennas are inserted into tumors to heat and kill them (typically utilizing the same frequency used by the microwave oven in your home). These devices offer minimally invasive, fast, and low-cost treatment for localized cancer tumors and potentially other diseases. All existing clinical microwave ablation systems produce a roughly spherical treatment zone near the tip and centered around the applicator shaft. Most clinical microwave ablation procedures are currently conducted to treat liver cancer, but microwave ablation is often not suitable for treating tumors with irregular shapes or those located near critical anatomy. The technical limitation preventing broader microwave ablation clinical use is lack of spatial control of the treatment zone. This limitation often leaves doctors with a difficult choice of risking undertreatment and disease recurrence or risking overtreatment and damage to healthy tissues that may cause pain or life-threatening complications and as a result typically restricts the use of microwave ablation for treating more types of cancers in other organs. Instead, our directional microwave ablation applicator enables the doctors to more precisely direct the treatment zone toward the tumor and away from sensitive healthy tissues. The broader impact of our work is that doctors may soon be able to adopt a low-cost, fast, minimally-invasive directional microwave ablation procedures to treat hundreds of thousands more cancer (such as lung, kidney, and late-stage bone cancer) patients or millions of patients with other conditions (such as benign adrenal tumors which cause high blood pressure) each year.

Because antennas with physically larger dimensions are typically more directional, but medical devices should be as small as possible to minimize invasiveness, developing a needle-like directional microwave ablation applicator was a technically challenging process. This project demonstrated intellectual merit though the development of advanced computational models and simulations that were utilized to design and optimize industrialized versions of our directional microwave ablation technology. It also successfully incorporated new materials and manufacturing processes into our microwave antenna design to improve device performance, reliability, and clinical usability. Finally, this project’s benchtop experiments validated the ability to provide new spatial control of the treatment zone in a directional microwave ablation applicator and its animal studies validated clinical users could successfully operate our system in a clinically relevant environment. During the course of this project, our team was granted two patents covering the design our directional microwave ablation applicator (which were originally filed prior to this award) and produced two journal papers. The first, titled Shaping the future of microwave tumor ablation: a new direction in precision and control of device performance and published in the International Journal of Hyperthermia, reviews the strengths and weaknesses of conventional MWA technology relative to our directional microwave ablation technology and highlights important clinical use cases for directional microwave ablation. The second, titled Directional Microwave Ablation in Spine: Experimental Assessment of Computational Modeling is currently under review for publication in the International Journal of Hyperthermia and presents our results from our pre-clinical in vivo animal studies conducting directional microwave ablation in spine. Findings from this work also supported a new line of investigations involving a real-time approach for monitoring microwave ablation procedures for which we raised follow-on funding from NCIs SBIR program.

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2024
Modified by: Austin Pfannenstiel
